Campus

Where We Cry

The Daily Californian is collecting stories about students crying on campus.

By Avni Prasad and Emily Zhong
NOVEMBER 3, 2017
UPDATED: NOVEMBER 5, 2017

For our upcoming special issue on mental health, The Daily Californian is creating an interactive map for readers to share their experiences of crying at UC Berkeley.

If you’re comfortable, tell us about a time you cried and where it happened, be it a hidden corner in Dwinelle Hall or the middle of Memorial Glade. Also include why you were crying, whether you were happy or sad. Reviewed submissions will be added to the map.

Content warning: Some of the stories below deal with themes of depression and suicide.

Thank you for your response. It will be reviewed and added to the map.

Tell us about a time you cried in Berkeley.

Responses may be edited for clarity and length.

If you're comfortable with the Daily Cal reaching out to you, please leave your name and contact information here.

For those seeking help, UC Berkeley’s Tang Center offers counseling services and resources for mental health.

The Crisis Text Line offers free, 24/7 emotional support for those in crisis via text messaging. To use the service, text HOME to 741741.

The City of Berkeley also has a Mobile Crisis Team that aims to reduce the impact of mental health emergencies. Its phone number is 510-981-5900.

Questions, comments or corrections? Email projects@dailycal.org.
